comment.body:
Oh no! D:

How did you join red?
oh... your blue hub circle is red...
I can see both of your posts again...
p2p: I noted some errors under that post, which might help nofish if you could recover them
That hub's name is very misleading. :(
I only see the hubs on ZeroHello.
That episode was incredibly strange.

GNU doesn't have intentional malware.  There are too many people looking at the code for something really malicious to be sneaked in.  However, open source projects have had some disastrous security flaws which allowed network exploits; look up Heartbleed, Shellshock, and Stagefright.
I'd like to see these in the ZeroHello newsfeed.
Controversial... more ways to respond to a post would be nice.  Sometimes "like" isn't really appropriate.

@ZAlex: sorry :(

You could increase the site size in the sidebar.  It should update normally then.
There's another: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Nvy3xR9hzqnTy4CimTVj8YuVVBFHAF578
ZeroLimit(s) was announced here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1N5Rs6CHsGPdDB1y3JqjYm9SLSWUTkjwEF
Since torcache went offline with KAT, you could get .torrent downloads working again by linking to itorrents.org instead.
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GKFwRvtkY1gcbMxm9vuZnz3THfnUP9zz/ works in Chrome but not Firefox.  Would a hybrid work in both, or neither?
@PaintNinja: it just plays from a local file (hosted on some other site).
@Musickiller: in ZeroTalk also, old topics are sometimes overwritten.  The correct sequence number must be getting lost somewhere.
@Nobite: webtorrent made their own incompatible protocol... so everyone has to use a client that knows what webtorrent is.
@megfault: it does use the same data, but most torrent clients can't communicate with webtorrent clients.

Did you know your player supports wav?

http://127.0.0.1:43110/15F9LYs6c17NUXv3MxpJSGbpWxyHTEbzMk/stream/audio.html?audioFile=magnet:?xt=urn:btih:9f585bd5667fbb2651a3ae3e7f60ae234466b6c2&dn=01+The+Universe+Fights+Back.wav&tr=wss%3A%2F%2Ftracker.webtorrent.io
I think @nofish plans to add categories.  Priorities and better organization for ZeroHello would make it more practical to seed many sites.
Someone started to mirror The Intercept, but never finished uploading.  Maybe ZeroNet could get some recognition there.
@Nofish: I think that would be enough for most people.  The ZeroHello search has the same limitation.

Have you seen these?
http://127.0.0.1:43110/192dZ1EG5tU7PnCfuwGMDEBrr2eLqvs4t3/?Category:books
http://127.0.0.1:43110/15rm8ew4pamdiFmpyYwzmEqJVx6Etnv8pP/
http://127.0.0.1:43110/13NS3rSzCTpAYtH997rphfZDaWRypyjwnU/

@Nobite: it has a Hackers/Fight Club theme which is a little implausible, but it's produced well.  The episode titles are amusingly written in 1337 as if they were video filenames.  In the second season, I think they're running out of file extensions.
Where are they?
You answered me before I asked.  o_O
@Talnicrom: I can see messages from @theterminator and @reginageorge in the activity feed, but not in the main feed.
Which hub are they posting comments to?

[ZeroISR](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12oGb8xBjLYz23CGJxRQyzZ6mGybZokEKt/) has 620MB of optional files.  I haven't seen ZeroNet using "GB" anywhere; maybe there are problems for sites that large.  The Intercept mirror grew continuously without updating content.json.
@FraYoshi: that's an IP address from mynameislegion's local network.  Everyone else needs to use 127.0.0.1 (localhost).
@Mynameislegion: they'll probably be asked to increase the limit to 50MB.
@Mynameislegion: there are some strange issues with getting them to work: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1mytj22YfKjQujw9Fo43WBwSJB658vqyY/Optional+Files
[IOL](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1PYydUXYkUMNyrUNxr6SzJG68z8qkCbc2v/) has "195326.26MB" of optional files.

@Fav: was it just a lucky accident that your address contains Fav?  (17gEFavobc7RsKNGbSzZwoSZ6jNB7hT2KN)

Also, we have http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeromedia.bit/ and some other chat sites.

@arsenelupin, @makdisse, and I are interested in a ZeroNet library, with probably three different ideas about where the content should be hosted.  Merger sites would help to organize categories.

I think @makdisse wants transparent compression support just because The Corsair has such a huge torrent index:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/1LkRBTdWeynXXmUhb5DXxesygs2aKaUnXx/3

@arsenelupin wants a wiki in ZeroNet linking to files in IPFS:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/137PNA5gLgCTLZTBtzUqCmMoZ752NQGQSJ/2

I have two sites each hosting one PDF only (http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EmfJvSsZWtikUqWnHbhMQ9yV5ATUBEooc/ and http://127.0.0.1:43110/1KuwNEQXaF7SmAibxLs2wgJQJjGYTDMErc/).  Any number of these could be indexed by a collection of merger sites.

I'm also holding Torrent Project's verified torrents index online, in case they have prolonged outages (as they have now; http://127.0.0.1:43110/16iXY7BX8UF1j2NJVQHADyuGorFJKFvnzG/).  A merger site using their categories would be more natural for ZeroNet.

@Mynameislegion: ZeroNet always tries to download content.json from someone else, even if you own the site.  It seems to need at least five peers to have a good chance of uploading for the first time and then downloading.  Large sites might be slow to transfer the file.
If you check `man console_codes`, the sequence that switches to VT100 box-drawing characters is `\e(0`.  You could `echo -e '\e(B'` to restore the default.

@Talnicrom: it seems like the hardest problem is the five peer minimum.  Reducing that could help a lot with keeping sites available.  Finding a way to reuse connections among peers sharing the same sites could help with potential upper limits.
I have a playlist like that too.
Here, 13 hours more. https://noisechannel.bandcamp.com/album/nc062-smiletron-archives :P
@Nofish: is some scripting supported?
Especially for animation the compression ratio can be very good.  Some encoders have problems with blocking and banding in dark scenes, so for live action I still look for x264.
The most recent episode was very good.

Every ZeroNet site also accepts donations through the "donate" link in the sidebar.  @bot says there have been few donations to any site; maybe there is not enough awareness of what can be done with bitcoin site addresses.  It might help if @nofish moved the address and link to just under the globe.  Nobody pays attention to the second page.

http://xkcd.com/378/
Is that a very small ordinary hard drive in a PC card?  What do `hdparm -i`/`-I`/`smartctl -x` say about it?  Could it be configured for the wrong multiple sector mode?

@Musickiller: `hdparm -m` would adjust multiple sector mode.  I think that wouldn't apply to flash.  Since it's flash, could it be unable to read individual blocks of only 512 bytes?  (maybe it has to operate on 32k at a time?)
@Musickiller: `dd bs=512 if=/dev/sdb of=8GB` might work.  Then you could dig through the image from a device with better support.
Not quite complete, there are two episodes left in this season.

Probably for the best that we can't embed instantly downloading links to anywhere on the internet, but relative image links are a nice idea.  @nofish?  How well could links between sites be supported?
@Nofish: could the cross-site links be allowed only for already seeded sites?
haha, 20GB limit

It's good to have plain HTML links for everything.  The donation address at the bottom could be linked to `bitcoin:1Jug5JKhDfL8RzGkJX2KRuUrSwjYBh3Lzk`, which would load it into a bitcoin client without copy+paste.

@Mynameislegion: even if names were hidden, ZeroNet would still have to record what was posted by each user.  If you don't want to be linked to a post, you could create a new ID.  You might ask [@userzero](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit/?to=userzero) to allow IDs from more sources (for example, [KaffieID](http://127.0.0.1:43110/id.kaffie.bit) or [Nanasi](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16KzwuSAjFnivNimSHuRdPrYd1pNPhuHqN/)).
